choices.text: It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist
It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel
Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about prasugrel? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a pro-drug

 

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is metabolized by the liver to its active metabolite, which is an inhibitor of P2Y12 ADP platelet receptors. This active metabolite irreversibly inhibits platelet aggregation, making prasugrel a potent antiplatelet agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist: It acts as an P2 Y12 agonist is incorrect because prasugrel is not a P2Y12 agonist but rather an inhibitor.

 

Option B It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel: It is 10 times less potent than clopidogrel is incorrect because prasugrel is actually more potent than clopidogrel.

 

Option D. Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding: Omeprazole interferes with metabolism of prasugrel leading to increased risk of bleeding is incorrect because omeprazole can interfere with the activation of prasugrel to its active metabolite, reducing its antiplatelet effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prasugrel is a pro-drug that, upon hepatic metabolism, becomes an active metabolite that irreversibly inhibits the P2Y12 ADP platelet receptors, thus preventing platelet aggregation and making it a potent antiplatelet agent.

questions.text: In a Pulmonary Function Test at what volume or capacity does the pressure measured at the upper airway reach zero?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional residual capacity

 

  • The functional residual capacity is the volume of the air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration. It is measured by a spirometer.
  • FRC → ERV + RV
  • At the lung volume corresponding to functional residual capacity (FRC), the lungs are in a relaxed state, and the pressure inside them becomes virtually negligible.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Residual volume: Incorrect. Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation, but it does not correspond to the point where airway pressure is zero.

 

Option C. Total lung capacity: Incorrect. Total lung capacity is the maximum amount of air the lungs can hold, which includes all lung volumes, but it does not correspond to zero airway pressure.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: Incorrect. Inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled after a normal expiration, but it does not correspond to zero airway pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional residual capacity is the lung volume at which the pressure in the upper airway reaches zero, indicating a relaxed state of the lungs.

questions.text: The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6th cranial nerve

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the 6th cranial nerve, also known as the abducens nerve. This can be remembered using the" This means that the Superior Oblique muscle is innervated by the 4th cranial nerve, the Lateral Rectus by the 6th cranial nerve, and the rest of the extraocular muscles are innervated by the 3rd cranial nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 3rd cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve) innervates most of the extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique, but not the lateral rectus.

 

Option B. 4th cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 4th cranial nerve (trochlear nerve) innervates only the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option D. 7th cranial nerve:  Incorrect. The 7th cranial nerve (facial nerve) is not involved in eye movement; it primarily controls facial muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the 6th cranial nerve (abducens nerve).

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presented with generalized fatigue and lethargy. Her general examination revealed a few superficial lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions. Labs – TC: 7400, Hb: 12.8 g/dL, and Platelets: 244,000. She had a normal DC and lymph node biopsy revealed architectural distortion, infiltration with cells with indented nucleus, and prominent nucleolus containing atypical cells. Immunophenotyping showed CD10 and Bcl2 were positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Follicular Lymphoma

 

The diagnosis of follicular lymphoma is supported by several key features in this patient's presentation and pathology findings:

 

  • Architectural distortion and infiltration with atypical cells: These findings on lymph node biopsy are consistent with follicular lymphoma.
  • Immunophenotyping: The presence of CD10 and Bcl2 positivity is characteristic of follicular lymphoma. CD10 is a marker indicating origin from the germinal center, and Bcl2 positivity suggests the presence of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl2, which is a hallmark of follicular lymphoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkitt Lymphoma: Burkitt lymphoma is associated with c-myc overexpression due to the t(8;14) translocation. It often presents with a high proliferation index and does not typically express Bcl2.

 

Option B. Hodgkin Lymphoma: Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. Sometime, PD1 overexpression. Immunophenotyping usually shows CD15 and CD30 positivity, not CD10 and Bcl2.

 

Option C. Mantle Cell Lymphoma: Mantle cell lymphoma is characterized by cyclin D1 overexpression due to the t(11;14) translocation. It is usually CD5 and cyclin D1 positive, not CD10 and Bcl2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma often presents with lymphadenopathy and generalized symptoms such as fatigue. Key diagnostic features include CD10 and Bcl2 positivity on immunophenotyping, reflecting its germinal center origin and overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl2.

questions.text: All among the following are clinical features of necrotizing enterocolitis except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metabolic alkalosis

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a serious gastrointestinal problem that mostly affects premature infants. It involves infection and inflammation that causes destruction of the bowel (intestine) or part of the bowel.

 

This is not a typical feature of NEC. Instead, NEC can cause metabolic or respiratory acidosis due to the severe infection and inflammation affecting the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

The typical clinical features of NEC include:

 

Option A. Vomiting: Vomiting is a common symptom in infants with NEC due to gastrointestinal dysfunction.

 

Option B. Abdominal mass: In severe cases, an abdominal mass can be palpated due to distended bowel loops filled with gas or fluid.

 

Option C. Erythema of the abdominal wall: This is seen in advanced stages of NEC, indicating severe inflammation and possible progression to perforation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) can cause metabolic or respiratory acidosis, not metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Stellate granuloma is seen in: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cat scratch disease

 

Stellate granuloma is seen in cat-scratch disease. It is also called as subacute regional lymphadenitis.

 

It is a bacterial infection caused by Bartonella henselae. Acquired following contact with infected animals (commonly cats).

 

Regional lymph nodes demonstrate:

 

  • Follicular hyperplasia with circumscribed central stellate necrosis with neutrophils
  • Surrounded by palisading histiocytes (suppurative granulomas)
  • Sinuses packed with monocytoid B cells
  • Usually, there are no perifollicular and intrafollicular epithelioid cells

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Absolute contraindication for breastfeeding is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactosemia

 

Explanation:

 

Galactosemia is a rare genetic disorder where the body cannot properly metabolize galactose, a sugar present in breast milk and many other foods. Infants with galactosemia are unable to break down galactose and its accumulation can lead to severe complications. Therefore, breastfeeding is an absolute contraindication for infants with galactosemia, and they require a special galactose-free formula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HIV: This option is incorrect. While HIV can be transmitted through breast milk, the transmission risk can be significantly reduced by antiretroviral therapy (ART) and other precautions. In certain situations, such as in resource-limited settings where safe alternatives to breastfeeding are not available, the benefits of breastfeeding may outweigh the risks of HIV transmission. However, in areas where safe and affordable alternatives are accessible, avoiding breastfeeding is generally recommended for infants born to HIV-positive mothers.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B: This option is incorrect. Breastfeeding is not an absolute contraindication for infants born to mothers with hepatitis B. Transmission of hepatitis B through breast milk is considered low, and the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that infants receive the hepatitis B vaccine and a dose of hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) within 12 hours of birth to prevent transmission. Breastfeeding can generally continue in these cases.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus infection: This option is incorrect. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) can be transmitted through breast milk, but the transmission risk can be reduced. In most cases, breastfeeding is not an absolute contraindication for infants with CMV infection. Precautions such as pasteurization of breast milk or using frozen breast milk from before the infection occurred can be taken to reduce the risk of transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The question aims to identify conditions where breastfeeding is absolutely contraindicated. Understanding absolute contraindications for breastfeeding is crucial for ensuring the safety and health of both the neonate and the mother. In certain medical conditions, breastfeeding can pose significant health risks to the infant, necessitating alternative feeding methods.

choices.text: Radiation exposure in CT scan is 20mSv
CT is the initial investigation for gallstones

questions.text: Identify the correct statement: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HU of water is zero

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) is a measure of radiodensity used in computed tomography (CT) scanning. By definition, the HU of water is zero, and this value serves as the reference point for measuring the density of other tissues. Values greater than zero indicate substances denser than water (e.g., bone, contrast material), while values less than zero indicate less dense substances (e.g., fat, air).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT uses non-filtered X-rays: This statement is incorrect. CT scans use filtered X-rays to remove low-energy X-rays that would not contribute to image formation but would increase patient radiation exposure.

 

Option B. Radiation exposure in CT scan is 20mSv: This is incorrect. Typical radiation doses for CT scans vary based on the body part being imaged. A head CT scan, for instance, typically involves a radiation dose of around 2 mSv, while an abdominal CT scan might be around 5 mSv. A dose of 20 mSv would be exceedingly high for a single CT scan.

 

Option C. CT is the initial investigation for gallstones: This is incorrect. Ultrasound is the initial investigation of choice for gallstones due to its high sensitivity, specificity, and lack of ionizing radiation. CT is more commonly used for other types of stones, such as kidney stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) of water is zero, serving as a reference point for measuring the radiodensity of various tissues in CT imaging.

questions.text: What is the likely ECG change associated with Bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) QT prolongation

 

Explanation:

 

Bedaquiline is a modern anti-tubercular drug used primarily for the treatment of multidrug-resistant (MDR) and extensively drug-resistant (XDR) tuberculosis. One of the significant side effects of bedaquiline is QT prolongation.

 

QT prolongation is a measure of delayed ventricular repolarization, which can be seen on an ECG as an extended QT interval. This side effect is critical as it can predispose patients to potentially fatal arrhythmias, such as Torsades de Pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PR prolongation: This represents delayed atrioventricular conduction and is not a known side effect of bedaquiline.

 

Option C. ST elevation: This is typically associated with myocardial infarction and is not a side effect of bedaquiline.

 

Option D. Wide QRS: This indicates delayed intraventricular conduction and is not associated with bedaquiline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bedaquiline, an important drug for treating MDR and XDR tuberculosis, is known for causing QT prolongation on ECG.

 

Note - The "Q" in bedaquiline can be a mnemonic to remember this important side effect.

choices.text: The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption
The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock
The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion
The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Cuthbertson's metabolic ebb and flow responses to trauma?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response

 

Explanation

 

The "flow" phase (not "ebb") leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

 

Cuthbertson's ebb and flow response to trauma:

 

A short ebb phase characterized by hypometabolism occurs immediately after the injury and is characterized by a decrease in metabolic rate, oxygen consumption, body temperature, and enzymatic activity. The ebb phase is followed by a longer hypermetabolic flow phase marked by an increased catabolism, with a high oxygen consumption and an elevated resting energy expenditure rate.

 

The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock, which leads to an increased metabolic turnover, activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption: Correct, this describes the initial hypometabolic state following trauma.

 

Option B. The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock: Correct, marking the transition to a hypermetabolic state.

 

Option C. The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion: Correct, as it focuses on conserving energy immediately after trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The statement that the "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response is false. These processes are characteristics of the "flow" phase, which occurs after the initial ebb phase and involves increased metabolic activity and systemic responses aimed at recovery and defense.

questions.text: Which parameters would you utilize to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programmer? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Annual Blood Examination Rate

 

Annual blood examination rate (ABER): (Index of operational efficiency)

 

 

 

ABER is a critical parameter used to assess the efficiency of the malaria surveillance system under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Program. It reflects the proportion of the population that is being tested for malaria and helps determine the operational efficiency of the surveillance system. High ABER indicates effective surveillance and control measures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Annual parasitic incidence (API): Sophisticated measure of malaria incidence in a community

 

 

Option C. Slide positivity rate (SPR):

 

 

Option D. Slide falciparum rate: specifically measures the proportion of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum, the most severe form of malaria. It indicates the burden of P. falciparum in the population.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following with the respective ages of fusion: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

Ages of Fusion:

 

  1. Medial end of clavicle:
    • Age of Fusion: 21-25 years
    • Description: The medial end of the clavicle is one of the last bones to complete its growth and fusion, typically fusing between 21 and 25 years of age.
  2. Sacrum as a single bone:
    • Age of Fusion: 22-25 years
    • Description: The sacral vertebrae fuse to form a single sacrum typically between 22 and 25 years of age.
  3. Crista scapulae:
    • Age of Fusion: 50 years
    • Description: The crista scapulae, or the scapular spine, continues to undergo changes and does not completely fuse until around 50 years of age.

  4. Lambdoid suture:

    • Age of Fusion: 45 years
    • Description: The lambdoid suture, located at the back of the skull, typically fuses around 45 years of age.

     

Educational Objective:

 

The age of fusion are:

questions.text: During a surgical procedure on a patient exhibiting symptoms indicative of peritonitis, a diverticular rupture is observed, accompanied by fecal peritonitis. What would be the corresponding stage according to the Hinchey's classification? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage 4

 

Hinchey's Classification is used to describe the severity of perforated diverticular disease. It helps guide the management of diverticulitis by categorizing the condition into different stages based on the clinical presentation and severity of the disease.

 

Hinchey's Classification Stages:

 

  • Stage 0: Mild clinical diverticulitis with symptoms such as left lower quadrant abdominal pain, low-grade fever, and leukocytosis. Management typically includes oral antibiotics.
  • Stage Ia: Confined pericolic inflammation or phlegmon. This stage can be managed with antibiotics, with or without CT-guided drainage.
  • Stage Ib: Confined pericolic abscess. Similar to Stage Ia, management includes antibiotics, with or without CT-guided drainage.
  • Stage II: Distant abscess. This requires abscess drainage, often through percutaneous methods.
  • Stage III: Purulent peritonitis. This stage involves the presence of pus in the peritoneal cavity, usually managed with Hartmann's surgery.
  • Stage IV: Fecal peritonitis. This stage indicates the presence of fecal matter in the peritoneal cavity due to a perforated diverticulum, and it is managed with Hartmann's surgery.

 

In the given scenario, the patient has a diverticular rupture with fecal peritonitis, which corresponds to Stage IV in Hinchey's classification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage 1: Stage 1 is divided into Stage Ia and Stage Ib. Stage Ia involves confined pericolic inflammation or phlegmon, while Stage Ib involves a confined pericolic abscess. Neither of these stages includes peritonitis.

 

Option B. Stage 2: Stage 2 involves the presence of a distant abscess. This stage does not include peritonitis and is managed with abscess drainage.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Stage 3 involves purulent peritonitis, which includes the presence of pus in the peritoneal cavity. However, it does not involve fecal contamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hinchey's Classification of diverticulitis is essential for determining the appropriate management strategy. Stage IV in Hinchey's classification corresponds to fecal peritonitis, which requires immediate surgical intervention, typically Hartmann's surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of central cyanosis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypothermia

 

Central cyanosis occurs when there is a significant amount of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood, typically due to issues with oxygenation or hemoglobin abnormalities.

 

In contrast, hypothermia leads to peripheral cyanosis, not central cyanosis. In hypothermia, the blood flow is sluggish due to vasoconstriction, particularly in the extremities, which results in a bluish discoloration of the skin. However, the central organs typically remain oxygenated.

 

Other Options:

 

Central cyanosis can be caused by several factors:

 

Option A. Methemoglobinemia: This condition involves the presence of methemoglobin in the blood, which does not carry oxygen effectively, leading to central cyanosis.

 

Option B. Pulmonary Arteriovenous Fistula: This abnormal connection between an artery and a vein in the lungs allows blood to bypass the alveoli, leading to poorly oxygenated blood entering the systemic circulation, causing central cyanosis.

 

Option C. High Altitude: At high altitudes, the reduced atmospheric pressure leads to lower oxygen availability, causing hypoxemia and central cyanosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia causes only peripheral cyanosis due to sluggish blood flow, not central cyanosis

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is produced by: (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Kidney
  2. Liver
  3. Spleen
  4. Lung
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

Explanation:

 

Erythropoietin is a hormone primarily produced by the kidneys and to a lesser extent by the liver. In a healthy individual, the majority of erythropoietin (approximately 90%) is produced by the kidney, specifically by peritubular interstitial fibroblasts. These cells respond to hypoxia (low oxygen levels) by increasing the production of erythropoietin, which then stimulates the bone marrow to produce more red blood cells. The liver also contributes to erythropoietin production, particularly through sinusoidal cells, although it accounts for only about 10% of the hormone's production under normal conditions.

 

In certain pathological conditions, such as in some types of anemia (e.g., thalassemia major), the spleen may take on a role in erythropoietin production to compensate for the body's increased need for red blood cells. However, this is not the case in healthy individuals, which is why the spleen and other organs like the lung are not considered significant sources of erythropoietin under normal physiological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

3 and 4: While the spleen can contribute in pathological states, it is not a primary source under normal conditions, and the lung does not contribute to erythropoietin production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin is primarily produced by the kidneys, with the liver contributing to a lesser extent. Understanding the primary and secondary sources of erythropoietin is crucial, particularly in the context of conditions affecting red blood cell production.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden-onset perineal pain. On examination, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

The given scenario and image is most likely to be of Fournier gangrene which is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

 

FOURNIER’S GANGRENE

 

  • Synergistic gangrene of scrotum and perineum
  • Limited to skin and fascial planes - type of necrotising fasciitis
  • Never breaches the tunica, testis always spared
  • Risk factors - Low immunity, uncontrolled diabetes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases: Anti-gas gangrene serum is obsolete now.

 

Option B. Urinary diversion is the next step: Urinary diversion is not the next best step.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy must be done: Testes are preserved during debridement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fournier gangrene is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital for a follow-up after undergoing a total thyroidectomy. He reports experiencing perioral numbness that started three days after the surgery. Upon further investigation, the patient has no history of nerve damage, facial trauma, or dental procedures. What diagnostic tests should be conducted to determine the cause of the perioral numbness? NEET PG 2022
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Calcium, Phosphate and Parathormone levels

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of post-operative hypocalcemia, likely due to ischemia of all 4 parathyroid glands or their accidental removal.
  • To assess the possibility of hypoparathyroidism following thyroidectomy, the patient's levels of calcium, phosphate, and parathyroid hormone (PTH) should be evaluated.
  • The patient's symptoms of perioral numbness after a total thyroidectomy raise suspicion for hypocalcemia due to potential damage to or inadvertent removal of the parathyroid glands during surgery or due to their ischemia.
  •  This option is the most appropriate for the patient's presentation. The parathyroid glands regulate calcium levels in the blood, and their ischemic damage or removal can result in hypocalcemia.
  •  By measuring calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels, one can assess the function of the parathyroid glands and determine if hypocalcemia is the cause of the patient's symptoms. If these levels are abnormal, it would confirm a diagnosis of hypoparathyroidism, which can manifest as symptoms like perioral numbness.
  • Symptoms of hypocalcemia may include circumoral paresthesia, paresthesia of the neck, fingers, and toes, muscle twitching, and weakness of the forearm, hand, and foot, as well as carpopedal spasms.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Serum Na, K, and Chloride: Deranged Na/K/Cl are unusual in the setting of thyroidectomy and do not corroborate with the patient’s clinical findings.

 

Option B. T3, T4, Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): These tests are used to evaluate overall thyroid function. These are not the primary tests to evaluate for post-operative hypocalcemia.

 

Option C. Radioiodine scan: This test uses a small amount of radioactive iodine to evaluate the structure and function of the thyroid gland. It's primarily used in the diagnosis and treatment of thyroid diseases like hyperthyroidism or to detect residual thyroid tissue after thyroidectomy in cases of thyroid cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia is a common complication due to potential damage or removal of the parathyroid glands.
  • It is important to measure serum calcium, phosphate, and parathormone (PTH) levels to diagnose and manage hypocalcemia in these patients.

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

 

The aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, but the right heart valves may also be involved in some cases.

 

Vegetations can be single or multiple, with one or more valves involved. Embolization is common and, due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli, can result in septic infarctions or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgment.

 

Other Options:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are a hallmark of infective endocarditis, characterized by the presence of bacterial colonies and significant inflammatory response.

 

Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis shows small, friable vegetations.

questions.text: Normal commensal conjunctival flora are: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staph. epidermidis

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common normal commensal flora found on the conjunctiva. This bacterium is typically found on human skin and mucous membranes, including the surface of the eye. It's important to note that while S. epidermidis is usually harmless, it can become opportunistic and cause infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals or following eye surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staph. aureus:  While S. aureus can be found on the conjunctiva, it's not as common as S. epidermidis and is more often associated with infections rather than normal flora.

 

Option C. H. influenzae:  This is not typically considered part of the normal conjunctival flora. It's more commonly associated with respiratory infections and can cause conjunctivitis when present in the eye.

 

Option D. Strep. pneumoniae:  This bacterium is not typically part of the normal conjunctival flora. It's more commonly associated with respiratory infections and can cause serious eye infections when present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common normal commensal flora of the conjunctiva. It's crucial to manage this normal flora during eye surgeries to prevent postoperative endophthalmitis. The use of povidone-iodine in the immediate pre-operative period is considered the best practice for preventing endophthalmitis by reducing the population of normal commensal flora on the ocular surface.

questions.text: During management of a labor in case of shoulder dystocia, a maneuver was done as shown below. This maneuver is known as? (FMGE jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cleidotomy

 

Explanation:

 

Cleidotomy is intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that requires to pass through the birth canal.

 

The table below enlists the manoeuvres used in the management of shoulder dystocia including the options A B C D

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cleidotomy is an intentional fetal clavicular fracture performed to reduce the shoulder girdle diameter in cases of shoulder dystocia.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th Edition Page 469-470

questions.text: A patient is brought to casualty and a whole-body CT scan has to be done. This CT scan will include the following except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CT Limbs

 

Whole body CT scan in context of trauma includes:

 

  • NCCT Head and C-spine
  • CECT Chest
  • CECT Abdomen

 

Limb injuries can be assessed by physical examination. Imaging is done in specific cases only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A whole-body CT scan for trauma includes NCCT of the head and C-spine, and CECT of the chest and abdomen, while limb injuries are typically evaluated through physical examination and imaged only when necessary.

questions.text: Which surgical procedure should a 21-year-old boxer avoid to maintain optimal visual health? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RK

 

  • For a 21-year-old boxer who needs to maintain optimal visual health, understanding the differences between various refractive surgeries is crucial. 

 

Involves making radial cuts in the cornea to change its shape and correct refractive errors. It's not recommended for boxers because it weakens the structural integrity of the eye, making it more vulnerable to trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PRK (Photorefractive Keratectomy): This surgery involves removing the surface layer of the cornea to reshape it with a laser. It is safer than RK for athletes because it does not involve creating a flap, which could dislocate upon impact, though recovery can be slower.

 

Option C. LASIK (Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis): LASIK surgery also reshapes the cornea but through creating a thin flap in the outer layer. While popular due to quick recovery times and immediate results, the flap might pose a risk in contact sports, as it could dislodge or move from direct impact.

 

Option D. SMILE (Small Incision Lenticule Extraction): The newest form of laser eye surgery, SMILE involves making a small, lenticule-shaped cut inside the cornea to reshape it without creating a flap. It offers a potentially safer option for athletes as it maintains more of the cornea's structural integrity.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For a boxer, avoiding procedures that compromise the cornea's physical integrity is crucial due to the high risk of impacts to the face. Among these options, RK and potentially LASIK present higher risks. SMILE or PRK might be safer alternatives, providing effective vision correction with a reduced risk of severe complications from physical trauma.

questions.text: A 2-month-old pregnant female presented with vivax malaria. She also had jaundice and confusion. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Quinine

 

Explanation

 

In the context of malaria treatment during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, safety of the medication is paramount.

 

For pregnant women in their first trimester with severe malaria (as indicated by symptoms like jaundice and confusion), quinine is the treatment of choice. Quinine is effective against severe malaria and is safer for use in early pregnancy compared to other options.

 

Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy due to potential hemolytic effects on the fetus, and doxycycline is also contraindicated due to risks of teratogenicity and dental staining.

 

Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are generally avoided in the first trimester due to insufficient safety data, despite being the preferred treatment in non-pregnant adults and in later stages of pregnancy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Chloroquine + Primaquine: Primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Option C. Doxycycline: Contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenic effects.

 

Option D. Artemisinin Combination Therapy: Not recommended in the first trimester due to insufficient safety data.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Quinine is the preferred treatment for severe malaria in pregnant women during the first trimester due to its safety profile compared to other antimalarial medications.

questions.text: Treatment of open fracture of femur: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open reduction and external fixation 

 

OPEN FRACTURES

 

  • An open fracture occurs when the bone breaks through the skin. 
  • These typically result from high-energy injuries and are often associated with significant damage to the surrounding soft tissues and contamination of the wound. 
  • These injuries are classified into three types according to the Gustillo-Anderson Classification:

 

 

  • All open fractures are emergencies.
  • These injuries require immediate administration of antibiotics and irrigation and debridement of the wound. 
  • The goal of the treatment is to achieve fracture healing and to prevent wound infections and osteomyelitis. 
  • They are frequently associated with injuries to surrounding vessels and nerves, which must be addressed as well. 
  • When the wound is contaminated, an external fixator is initially used. 
  • Early coverage of the wound is important to avoid infection. 
  • Immediately debride the wound of contaminated and devitalized tissue, copiously irrigate, and repeat debridement within 24-72 hours (Delayed wound closure is preferable).
  • Type and method of fixation:

 

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin –Ilizarov fixator.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Closed reduction and internal fixation: Closed reduction is not done for an open fracture. An open fracture inherently involves a break in the skin and contamination. It requires surgical exploration, debridement, and irrigation of the wound in the operating room. Attempting a closed reduction would significantly increase the risk of deep infection (osteomyelitis). Internal fixation (e.g., with an intramedullary nail) can be used for less severe open fractures (Gustilo-Anderson Type I, II, and sometimes IIIA), after thorough open debridement. However, the combination with closed reduction makes this option incorrect for an open fracture.

 

Option D. Closed reduction and external fixation: Closed reduction is incorrect for an open fracture due to the necessity of open wound management. External fixation is a valid and often preferred method of stabilization for open fractures, particularly severe ones or as a temporary measure. However, the initial phase must involve open management of the wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The open fractures are best treated with open reduction and external fixation with the use of external fixators like ilizarov fixator.

choices.text: It has one artery and two veins
It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly
Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies
Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the umbilical cord? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It has one artery and two veins

 

Explanation:

 

  • The umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein.
  • This 3 vessel umbilical cord appears as a “mickey-mouse sign” manner on the ultrasound finding
  • The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus and the 2 umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly: Wharton’s jelly is the gelatinous material surrounding the umbilical cord which protects it from external forces

 

Option C. Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies: A single umbilical artery is the most common anomaly in an umbilical cord.

 

It is associated with congenital anomalies such as genitourinary and cardiac anomalies

 

It may also be associated with Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome) and other chromosomal anomalies

 

Option D. Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm: The average length of the umbilical cord is 50 cm

 

Educational objective:

 

The umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein.

 

Ref: Page no 44, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following methods uses RNA? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) RT-PCR

 

  • RT-PCR is a molecular biology technique used to amplify and analyze RNA.
  • It involves the conversion of RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcription, followed by PCR amplification of the cDNA.
  • RT-PCR is specifically used for RNA analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Western blot:

  • Western blotting is a technique used to detect and analyze proteins.
  • It involves the separation of proteins by gel electrophoresis and their subsequent transfer to a membrane for detection using antibodies specific to the protein of interest.
  • Western blotting primarily deals with proteins, not RNA.

 

Option C. Sanger's method (Sanger Sequencing):

  • Sanger sequencing is a DNA sequencing technique developed by Frederick Sanger.
  • It is used to determine the nucleotide sequence of DNA strands.
  • Sanger sequencing deals with DNA, not RNA.

 

Option D. G-banding:

  • G-banding is a cytogenetic staining technique used to visualize and analyze the banding patterns of chromosomes.
  • It is used in karyotyping and primarily focuses on the visualization of chromosomal DNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RT-PCR is a method for detection of gene expression using reverse transcription of RNA to synthesize cDNA. Western Blot most commonly involve antigen-antibody interactions which is a.protein-protein interaction. Sanger’s method is a DNA sequencing technique by chain termination of DNA polymerization using DNA as template. G-banding is a chromosomal staining technique usually done for karyotyping analysis and involve only DNA.

 

Ref- Lehninger 6th e/p 331

questions.text: During resuscitation in a patient with severe hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias, a patient received a 20% Intralipid injection. What could have been the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Local anesthesia toxicity

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used as a treatment for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). If a patient accidentally receives an excessive dose of local anesthetic, or if the local anesthetic is inadvertently injected into a blood vessel, it can lead to systemic toxicity, manifesting as CNS symptoms (like seizures) and cardiovascular collapse. Intralipid acts as a lipid sink, effectively reducing the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma and thereby reversing the toxic effects. This is why this option is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asphyxia due to drowning: While drowning can certainly lead to hypotension and arrhythmias, it does so because of hypoxia and other related complications. Intralipid injection is not a recognized treatment for drowning and its consequences.

 

Option C. Electrocution: While electrocution can cause cardiac arrhythmias and other cardiac problems, the primary treatment is to address the rhythm disturbances directly, treat burns, and support the patient. Intralipid would not be used in this context.

 

Option D. Pulseless electrical activity (PEA): PEA refers to a condition where there is organized or semi-organized electrical activity in the heart (seen on EKG) but no palpable pulse. The treatment for PEA is high-quality CPR, following the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) algorithm, and addressing any potential reversible causes. Intralipid is not a standard treatment for PEA.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used specifically for treating local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) by acting as a lipid sink to reduce the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 885

questions.text: A laboratory technician is analyzing cell populations using flow cytometry. This technique allows for the simultaneous multiparametric analysis of the physical and/or chemical characteristics of single cells flowing through an optical and/or electronic detection apparatus. Which visual depictions are commonly generated in flow cytometry for the evaluation of these cell populations? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Histogram, dot plot

 

  • Histogram and Dot plot can be used to depict flow cytometry analysis.
  • Histogram can be used to compare single parameter (1D)

 

 

 Scatter/Dot plot are used to compare 2 or 3 parameters (2D; 3D)

 

 

Flow Cytometry is used to detect and measure physical and chemical characteristics of a population of cells or parameters like cell counting, sorting, detect microorganisms, detect neoplasm and various more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In flow cytometry, histograms and dot plots are the common visual depictions for evaluating cell populations.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in low insulin: glucagon ratio?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Activation of hormone-sensitive lipase

 

In a fasting state, insulin decreases and glucagon increases, hence there is Low insulin: glucagon ratio. Since insulin has an inhibitory effect on hormone-sensitive lipase, low insulin: glucagon ratio results in the activation of hormone-sensitive lipase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Activation of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is promoted by insulin, but here it is low. Lipoprotein lipase enzyme breaks triglycerides (TGs) of Lipoproteins (Chylomicrons and VLDL) to give 3 fatty acids and glycerol.

 

Option B. Activation of glycogen synthase is promoted by insulin (fed state). In low insulin: glucagon ratio, glycogen synthase activity will be reduced, leading to decreased glycogenesis.

 

Option C. Activation of phosphoructokinase-1 (PFK1) is promoted by insulin (fed state). PFK1 is a rate-regulating enzyme in glycolysis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hormone-sensitive lipase is present inside the cells of adipose tissues. Stored triglycerides in adipose tissues are broken by HSL into 3 fatty acids and glycerol. 3 fatty acids go in blood and then are taken by liver where β- Oxidation of fatty acids (catabolic) occurs to give energy in Liver.

 

In diabetic patients, low insulin level which causes an increase in HSL activity, promoting the breakdown of lipids and the release of FFAs from adipose tissue. HSL activity is accelerated by hormones like epinephrine, norepinephrine, glucagon, ACTH, TSH, GH, ADH, and melanocyte-stimulating hormones (MSH).

choices.text: Routine Ha & E

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amyloidosis

 

The given image demonstrates Congo red stain showing Pink red appearance under normal light. This stain is used in diagnosis of Amyloidosis.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Elastic fibers: Elastic fibers can be demonstrated by Verhoeff-van Gieson Stain.

 

 

Option B. Routine H & E: Routine H & E is done by Hematoxylin and eosin stain. The hematoxylin stains cell nuclei a purplish blue, and eosin stains the extracellular matrix and cytoplasm pink.

 

 

Option D. Collagen: Collagen can be demonstrated by Masson trichrome stain. It gives blue color to the collagen, black color to nuclei and red to muscle present.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congo red staining, showing pink-red deposits under normal light, is characteristic of amyloid and is a key diagnostic tool for amyloidosis.

questions.text: In a fetal monitoring, which of the following factors primarily contributes to an increase in fetal heart rate acceleration during labor and delivery, signifying fetal well-being? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carotid body chemoreceptors

 

The carotid body chemoreceptors play a crucial role in monitoring and responding to changes in blood oxygen levels, particularly during labor and delivery. These receptors are highly sensitive to decreases in blood oxygen levels (hypoxia) and increases in carbon dioxide levels (hypercapnia). When activated, they send signals to the brainstem to increase respiratory rate and heart rate, thereby ensuring adequate oxygen supply to the fetus.

 

During labor, the fetus can experience transient periods of hypoxia due to contractions and reduced placental blood flow. The carotid body chemoreceptors detect these changes and contribute to fetal heart rate acceleration, which is an important indicator of fetal well-being.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Aortic baroreceptors: Incorrect. Aortic baroreceptors are primarily involved in regulating blood pressure by detecting changes in arterial pressure and activate cardio-vagal (Parasympathetic) center. Their activation leads to reduction in fetal heart rate (not acceleration).

 

Option C. Autonomic brain stem regulation: Incorrect. While the autonomic brainstem plays a role in overall cardiovascular regulation, the direct response to hypoxia and resulting heart rate acceleration is mediated by chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. ANP (Atrial Natriuretic Peptide): Incorrect. ANP is involved in regulating blood volume and pressure by promoting sodium and water excretion, but it does not directly influence fetal heart rate acceleration during labor.

 

Educational Objective

 

Carotid body chemoreceptors are primarily responsible for detecting changes in blood oxygen levels and contributing to fetal heart rate acceleration during labor, indicating fetal well-being.

choices.text: It is faster than AV nodal pathway
It is slower than AV nodal pathway

questions.text: Identify the false statement about the bundle of Kent? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is slower than AV nodal pathway

 

The false statement about the bundle of Kent is that it is slower than the AV nodal pathway. In fact, the bundle of Kent provides a rapid conduction pathway between the atrium and the ventricle, bypassing the AV node. This pathway allows for faster conduction than the AV nodal pathway due to the nature of the myocardial fibers involved and the lack of delay that normally occurs at the AV node.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is faster than the AV nodal pathway: This statement is actually true. The bundle of Kent facilitates faster electrical conduction from the atria to the ventricles by bypassing the slower AV node, contributing to the clinical manifestations of pre-excitation syndromes.

 

Option C. Leads to a short PR interval: This is true. The rapid conduction via the bundle of Kent results in premature activation of the ventricles, reflected as a shortened PR interval on an electrocardiogram.

 

Option D. Leads to a prolonged QRS duration: This is also true. The activation of ventricular myocardium via the accessory pathway occurs in a less synchronized manner compared to normal conduction through the His-Purkinje system, leading to a broader and prolonged QRS complex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bundle of Kent is an accessory pathway connecting atrium and ventricle with conduction through Na+ channels leading to bypass of physiological AV conduction.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/WPW

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hormone sensitive lipase

 

Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL). Hormone-sensitive lipase is responsible for the breakdown of triglycerides stored in adipose tissue into fatty acids and glycerol. When insulin levels are high, such as after a meal, it promotes fat storage and inhibits HSL activity, reducing the release of fatty acids from adipose tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lipoprotein lipase: Insulin activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL). Lipoprotein lipase is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the metabolism of lipoproteins, specifically in the hydrolysis of triglycerides in circulating chylomicrons and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL). Insulin promotes LPL activity, which facilitates the uptake of fatty acids into adipose tissue and muscle for storage and energy utilization.

 

Option C. Acid lipase: Insulin does not have a direct inhibitory effect on acid lipase. Acid lipase enzymes, such as gastric lipase and lysosomal lipase, function in different environments and processes compared to the regulation of lipids by insulin in the bloodstream.

 

Option D. Alkaline lipase: Insulin does not have a direct inhibitory effect on alkaline lipase. Alkaline lipases are typically found in the pancreas and function in the digestion of dietary fats. They are not directly regulated by insulin in the same way as the lipases involved in adipose tissue and circulating lipoprotein metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin is an anabolic hormone so activates anabolic enzymes and inhibits catabolic enzymes. Hormone sensitive lipase is a catabolic enzyme present in adipose tissue cells which causes release of fatty acids from stored TG during starvation. So, it is activated by catabolic enzyme Glucagon. Lipoprotein lipase on the other hand is an anabolic enzyme and release FA from TG of VLDL and chylomicrons in fed state. Understanding the regulatory role of insulin in lipase enzymes is essential for medical students. Insulin inhibits hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) to promote fat storage and activates lipoprotein lipase (LPL) to facilitate fatty acid uptake, which helps maintain energy homeostasis and lipid metabolism in the body.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 240, 245

choices.text: Growth of 103 coliform in suprapubic sample
Growth of 105 coliform in voided urine sample
Frequency with dysuria with positive nitrite and leucoesterase dipstick test

questions.text: Urinary tract infection in a pregnant lady in her 2nd trimester is best defined as: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Growth of 105 coliform in voided urine sample

 

Explanation:

 

A urinary tract infection (UTI) in a pregnant woman is best defined by the growth of 10^5 coliforms per milliliter in a voided urine sample. This threshold is used to differentiate significant bacterial growth from contamination or a non-infectious presence of bacteria.

 

In pregnancy, the standard diagnostic method for UTI is a urine culture. A growth of 10^5 or more coliforms per milliliter in a properly collected voided urine sample is considered diagnostic for UTI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Growth of 103 coliform in suprapubic sample: Growth of 10^3 coliforms in a suprapubic sample is not a standard criterion for diagnosing UTI. Typically, suprapubic aspiration is used for more precise diagnoses, and lower thresholds may be acceptable due to reduced contamination risk compared to voided samples. However, for voided samples, the threshold is higher.

 

Option C. Frequency with dysuria with >3 WBC/HPF: Frequency with dysuria and >3 WBC/HPF indicates inflammation and possible infection but does not define a UTI by itself. The presence of WBCs in urine is a sign of inflammation or infection but is not specific for diagnosis.

 

Option D. Frequency with dysuria with positive nitrite and leucoesterase dipstick test: Frequency with dysuria and positive nitrite and leucocyte esterase dipstick tests suggest a UTI but are not definitive. These tests are helpful as preliminary screening tools but are not as definitive as a quantitative urine culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A urinary tract infection in a pregnant lady in her 2nd trimester is best defined as the growth of 10^5 coliforms in a voided urine sample.

 

Ref: Page no 348, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 6th edition

questions.text: Identify this instrument used in laparoscopic surgery? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veress needle

 

The Veress needle is an instrument displayed in the image that is utilized to inflate the abdomen for laparoscopic surgery. In laparoscopic procedures, there are two ways of establishing abdominal access: the direct puncture technique (closed technique) and the open technique. The Veress needle is specifically used in the direct puncture laparoscopy method.

 

Lind's Needle: Lind's needle is a type of trocar and cannula system used in medical procedures, particularly for draining fluids or inserting catheters. It consists of a sharp, pointed needle (the trocar) that is enclosed within a cannula.

choices.text: Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.text: Brown Sequard syndrome is characterized by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side

 

Explanation

 

Brown-Sequard syndrome results from a hemisection (partial transection) of the spinal cord, leading to a distinct pattern of neurological symptoms:

 

  • Ipsilateral (same side as the lesion) Deficits:
    • Motor Function: There is paralysis below the level of the lesion due to damage to the corticospinal tract, which controls voluntary muscle movements. The paralysis is of the upper motor neuron type, characterized by increased muscle tone, spasticity, and hyperreflexia.
    • Proprioception and Discriminative Touch: Loss of fine touch, vibration sense, proprioception, and discriminatory tactile abilities due to damage to the dorsal columns (fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus) which carry these sensory modalities from the body to the brain.
  • Contralateral (opposite side as the lesion) Deficits:
    • Pain and Temperature Sensation: Loss occurs below the level of the lesion because the spinothalamic tract, which carries pain and temperature sensations, crosses over to the opposite side at the level of the spinal cord soon after entering. Thus, a hemisection will affect the fibers carrying information from the opposite side.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fine touch lost on the opposite side: Incorrect because fine touch is lost on the same side as the lesion, not the opposite.

 

Option B. Pain and temperature lost on the same side: Incorrect as pain and temperature sensations are lost on the opposite side due to the crossing of the spinothalamic tract.

 

Option D. Only pain lost on the same side: Incorrect because pain sensation is lost on the opposite side and is associated with temperature loss as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemi section of the spinal cord involves the ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Sequard syndrome.

 

 

Functions of tracts involved -

 

Fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus → ipsilateral discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception

 

Spinothalamic tract → contralateral pain and temperature sensation

 

Corticospinal tract → primary motor activity same side of the body.

questions.text: Which type of amputation is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Below knee amputation

 

The image shows an amputation where both the tibia and fibula are visible below the knee, which indicates a below-knee amputation. A dissected specimen of the tibia and fibula below the knee was shown, which matches the image provided. Below-knee amputations involve removing the lower limb while preserving the knee joint, improving the potential for prosthetic use and mobility in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Above knee amputation: This amputation occurs above the knee joint, where the entire knee and part of the femur are removed. However, the image does not show the knee joint being amputated.

 

Option C. Chopart’s amputation: This type of amputation occurs in the intertarsal region of the foot, which is not applicable in this image, as the amputation is clearly higher up, below the knee.

 

Option D. Lisfranc amputation: This refers to an amputation at the tarsometatarsal joint, which is also a lower limb amputation but located in the foot. The image shows an amputation above the foot, making this option incorrect.

 

Different types of amputations:

 

  1. Hip disarticulation: Removal at the hip joint (disarticulation from the joint).
  2. Above knee amputation: Removal above the knee.
  3. Knee disarticulation: Amputation through the knee joint.
  4. Below knee amputation: Removal below the knee.
  5. Syme's amputation: Amputation above the ankle.
  6. Boyd's or Pirogov amputation: Involves cutting the calcaneum (heel bone).
  7. Chopart's amputation: Involves the intertarsal area (just above the calcaneum).
  8. Lisfranc's amputation: Involves the tarsometatarsal joint (between the tarsal and metatarsal bones).
  9. Transmetatarsal amputation: Amputation in between the metatarsal bones.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A below-knee amputation involves the removal of the lower limb below the knee joint, preserving the knee, tibia, and fibula, which improves mobility and function compared to an above-knee amputation.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine Ca ratio > 0.15

 

Nutritional rickets is a disorder caused by vitamin D deficiency, leading to impaired bone mineralization and growth. The incorrect statement in the context of nutritional rickets is:

 

This is typically seen in primary hyperparathyroidism, not in secondary hyperparathyroidism like that seen in vitamin D deficiency or nutritional rickets. In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is usually low because of the body's attempt to conserve calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

The following points summarize the key biochemical features of nutritional rickets:

 

Option A. Normal Calcium: In many cases of nutritional rickets, serum calcium levels are normal or low-normal at the time of presentation due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, which compensates for the low calcium by increasing parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

Option B. Low Phosphate: Hypophosphatemia is common in rickets due to decreased intestinal absorption of phosphate and increased renal excretion.

 

Option D. High PTH: Secondary hyperparathyroidism occurs as a response to hypocalcemia, leading to elevated PTH levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium-to-creatinine ratio is typically low, not high. Elevated PTH, low phosphate, and normal calcium levels are typical biochemical findings in this condition.

questions.text: The green line corresponds to which vertebral level?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L5

 

Explanation:

 

The green line shown in the image corresponds to the trans-tubercular plane, which passes through the L5 vertebral level. The abdominal planes are used as anatomical landmarks to describe the location of structures and features within the abdomen. The important horizontal planes include:

 

  1. Transpyloric plane: Passes through the lower border of L1 vertebra.
  2. Subcostal plane: Passes through the upper border of L3 vertebra.
  3. Transtubercular plane: Passes through the upper border of L5 vertebra, as seen in the image.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L1: This corresponds to the transpyloric plane, which is higher up in the abdomen.

 

Option B. L3: This corresponds to the subcostal plane, located midway between the transpyloric and transtubercular planes.

 

Option D. T12: This vertebral level is not associated with the horizontal planes typically used in abdominal anatomy and is located in the thoracic region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transtubercular plane passes through the L5 vertebral level, and it is a key anatomical landmark in the lower abdomen.

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.text: A first year surgery resident, on rotation at a hospital, is tasked with inserting an intercostal drainage tube in a 65-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who was admitted with a severe exacerbation of their symptoms. The surgery resident has previously performed the procedure under supervision, but this is their first time doing it on their own. Which of the following steps is incorrect? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib

 

Explanation:

 

An intercostal drainage (ICD) tube should be inserted along the upper border of the lower rib, not the lower border of the upper rib. This is to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle, which runs along the lower border of each rib (comprising the intercostal vein, artery, and nerve). Inserting the tube along the lower border of the upper rib increases the risk of injuring these critical structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube: The 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line is a commonly selected site for the insertion of an ICD. This location is within the "triangle of safety," which is bounded by the lateral border of the pectoralis major anteriorly, the latissimus dorsi posteriorly, and the horizontal level of the nipple below. This area minimizes the risk of injuring important structures, including the long thoracic nerve and vessels.

 

Option C. Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury: Directing the tube posteriorly initially helps ensure that it enters the pleural space without injuring the lung. Once inside the pleural cavity, the direction of the tube may be adjusted based on the specific indication for the ICD, such as draining an effusion versus a pneumothorax.

 

Option D. Incised and digitally explored: After making a skin incision, blunt dissection and digital exploration are performed to ensure that there are no obstructions or adhesions and to create a safe pathway for the tube. Digital exploration helps confirm that the tube enters the pleural space properly and safely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When inserting an intercostal drainage tube, it is crucial to place the tube along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid damaging the neurovascular bundle that runs along the lower border of the upper rib.
